reviewText:
This has to be the most challenging platform game I’ve ever played; Super Meat Boy  (SMB) rises steadily in difficulty from easy to ridiculously hard core crazy.  After passing the first boss I had to stop simply because my tired old bones and aching hands were almost suffering from RSI .  That said; this is a beautifully executed game that will keep the   most dedicated of platformer fans wanting more.

SMB has an endearing  style of its own  (despite the copious  trails and splashes of blood with precisely  designed levels that  fit the theme of the game perfectly, plus  it takes me back to  the days when skill was   the most important  attribute for getting through  a level.  You'll need lots of that if you are to get to the   end of this game, especially unscathed.  I really don't know how anyone could get through a complete area without dying at least once.  You'd need to be superhuman, or   one of the best platformers in the world to beat   these levels.


You'll  often be  surprised or even relieved  at how short  some of the levels are (no more than about  30 seconds); that said, with a content of over 300 maps, bonus stages and hidden warp zones  that contain challenging extra-maps,  dark worlds (one for each stage, e.g. Salt Factory Dark World, Hell Dark World etc)  and,  not forgetting  the unlock-able characters which can be gained by collecting bandages that are placed in hard to get locations on several levels or   finishing warp zones - try getting through one of   the  main  stages or the hidden  dark worlds without dying to gain  achievements -  only  0.6% to 1% of the Meat boy community are  getting these achievements because they are ultra hard to  achieve.  Anyway, with all of these  extra's plus  using the editor, (which you'll find in your library under tools),  you have the potential to create unlimited  levels, that are only limited by your imagination, need for more levels  and stamina,  it's hard to get bored of this game. On top of that you're able to implement Maps made by the community.
If you don't already own SMB; now that its over 3 years old, you'll easily pick it up for a bargain price, especially in the many Steam sales that we get these days.

I highly recommend this game, despite me not  achieving much in the way of completing most of the levels  yet , (I've spent over 20 hours playing this game already and I'm still hungry for more)   nor getting  many of the in game achievements (couldn't be bothered  collecting the bandages, lol).  I certainly intend returning to the game when my hands have recovered from the deviously  executed level designs.


If you've not played this game  get it as soon as you can; maybe check out the demo (unfortunately Steam don't offer a demo download), or play the browser  based   flash game:
http://www.kongregate.com/games/edmund/meat-boy
to get a feel for the game.

Highly recommended and  a 9 out of 10 from me (it loses a point simply because  its a little too hard for me.

Last words:  It's one of the best platformers of the last decade in my opinion (apart from maybe Gish).

reviewText:
Super Meat Boy is a the creme de la creme of 2D challenging platformers. It stands out head and shoulders above the rest. It has a beautiful art style, cut scenes parodying old Nintendo games and a simple plot. A villain has taken Bandage Girl and you as Super Meat Boy must reach her at the end of every single level. When you get to her she gets whisked away time and time again. The 7 'chapters' each have around 20 levels that can get completed in 30 seconds or less. The real challenge here is that most everything causes instant death. Spikes, grinders, guns and pits. With each death, you respawn at the start with no load time. This keeps you in the game. Every chapter has its own theme including a forest, a hospital, a salt factory and even Hell itself. At the end of every level is a new and unique boss fight that usually consists of a race.

Even if people have branded it a difficult game, you will eventually get through the game with enough practice. Since there are no lives and you just respawn, there is no consequence. While completing a level just leads to the next level, there is an easy to use map so you can go back and replay areas. On top of that, for every 'grade A' (under par time) that you get for a level, you can play its dark world counterpart making levels tougher. In all around 300 levels.

Each level has their own gimmicks. Platform riding, touch bricks that dissolve, raising lava, shooting saw blades, conveyer belts and so on. Some levels even have keys that when touched they remove lock blocks automatically. There is a lot of variety here. The game ratchets up up the creativity with portals. Since Meat Boy is one block tall, he can fit most anywhere. Some levels have winding paths through factories. Others are broad jumps between conveyer belts that launch him into the area. There are warp zones to find in levels that will send you to far more difficult levels. All with simple controls.

As a square of meat, the controls are simple, left, right, jump and run. You can even jump off walls and slide down them. Sometimes your wall jump will slide you up from momentum. Other than that the game isn't slippery like other 2D platformers. Meat Boy can stop on a dime. Holding run and jump can fly you across the screen to where you need to be. The Steam version has plenty of unlockable characters from collecting band-aids in certain levels. You'll also get to play as other characters that have different abilities. At the end of each level you're treated to seeing all your failed attempts playing all at once.

There's not much to say about the game. Its charm, art and music make it more desirable to play than the average 2D challenging platformer. Super Meat Boy has a lot of content for your money, complete with a level designer to unlock. So many people like something that makes them throw their controllers.

reviewText:
Super Meat Boy is a 2D fast paced puzzle platforming indie game developed by Team Meat. And there is alot of meat here folks! More than any one player can handle apparently.

Where do I begin? Hmmmm... Let's see, I was a bit iffy about purchasing this game at first just because it's such been such a huge thing in the indie scene. My initial thought at first was that the game was over-rated and didn't deserve the glory that was bestowed on it. Boy....  or Meatboy rather... was I wrong! Super Meat Boy, in my opinion, is all about the feels... not the emotional feels though. I'm talking about how the game feels when playing the game using an Xbox 360/Xbox One controller. The game is wonderfully sensitive to your every movement. It's both sick and maddening. You'll have to be precise in every movement but I love that about the challenge of this game. I can't remember the last time I played a 2D platforming game which controlled so fluidly, felt so fair when dying yet rewarding when finishing a level, and had such clever level design. Truly, Super Meat Boy puts games like Super Mario Bros. to shame.

As you progress, the game gradually gets more and more difficult. The levels do not stop getting more difficult, they don't get in a stagnant place, this is one of the first games I think I've ever placed where the difficulty doesn't just dip, spike or flatline, rather intelligently keeps a steady case of increasing while introducing you to new environments to change up the variety of levels. The replayability is high, you are timed after all and not only do you have the primary goal of finishing the level but you also get ratings for how fast you finish and can collect objects in the envirinment which later unlocks characters or other things.

There are bosses at the end of each world, while these boss battles aren't what you'd probably expect, they do give you a keen sense of rewarding the player with accomplishment. Since you cannot attack as Meatboy, you basically have to get from point A to point B without dying. While that may sound boring, it's not. Team Meat has perfected the point A to point B formula and that's truly impressive.

Pros  Insane difficulty will please even the most hardcore gamers in the world
Controls feel extraordinarily smooth
Tons of levels
Meaty soundtrack
Unlockable characters
Exclusive HeadCrab character
Cons  Players will rage, give up and move on
Story could be told a little bit better
Final Thoughts:
I highly recommend this game if you favor platforming games or just a challenging game in general. It's the Hotline Miami of the Platforming genre. According to one of the guys who made this game, only 8% of people who have ever played the game have finished it and now it's probably even less. If you have a history of anger problems or domestic violence, you may want to steer clear of this game for your own safety.

Rating (9 out of 10)

reviewText: Super Meat Boy is simply put a masterpiece of the indie genre. I believe it will be studied in the not so distant future as the cornerstone it is. Its very tight controls, the awesome map layout, its great variety, the optimization of its mechanics and its humor are just some of the qualities that make it unique. The music is so great that I sometimes listen to it even when I’m not playing, the different characters offer different ways of beating the same levels and the way the game is divided into light and dark world is an awesome way of providing an additional challenge for those that crave for more.\n\nThe instant respawn, the original achievements, the boss stages and seeing all your deaths at the same time once you beat a level are just signs of how awesome this game is. Yes, you’ll probably rage quit anyway a few times, but after having a go at a difficult level for 50 times, you can do half of it with your eyes closed (seriously). It becomes such a mechanical action that I sometimes just used the time to think about other stuff and put my thoughts in order. It’s almost therapeutic. At the very end of the game, beating a stage could easily take me more than 60 minutes… and the worse is, that once you beat a level, you’re automatically ready for the next one. I’m terrible at this game (more than 50 hours and haven’t even done half of the dark world) but I still had a lot of fun. I’m ready to say goodbye, at least for now, to Super Meat Boy, but it will always hold a special place in my library (and my meaty heart). *dramatic chipmunk sound*

reviewText:
The main issue that Super Meat Boy has is that of being a precision platformer. There is a big reason peope dislike this genre. It is based more so around performing the exacts precise movement to get to the finish line instead of having various ways or approaches of finishing an obstacle. However, Super Meat Boy triumps this problem by being the best damn precision platformer ever.
-
First, how does SMB overcome the problems that come with a precision platformer? First, the level design is genuinely fun. Other than the couple final (bonus) levels where difficulty goes through the roof, it is built in such a way that before encountering a real obstacle, you get a level to learn the way it works without any big danger or work your way around it and even if you would get stuck, you can pretty much play the levels of an area in any order you want. This is a really good design choice as you may practice on whatever level you want. And if that is still not enough, there is the dark world mechanic (letting you play a harder version of the levels you beat in set time) that lets you practice on harder versions of levels.
-
Next, the unlockables have a big inpact on style of play. Unlike many other games where unlocked characters are there only for novelty value or very slight changes, here almost every character is useful. Whether it is to teach the new player and help him finish levels easier (Commander Video, Headcrab) or to make it possible for players to really break some levels if they know how to play (Flywrench, The Kid), all of these characters have a certain usefulness to them besides being fun. Not only that, but there are also bandages and warp zones. Overall, the game is just packed with content and lets you blaze through it at your own speed without making you rush into impossible challenges.
-
You cannot have a cool precision platformer without cool music and graphics. Super Meat Boy does both excellently. The graphics have a very nice style to them that makes them feel both detailed and simple. It's not a style that is done lazily or retro for the sake of being retro or overcomplicated, instead it does it's job- it makes you see everything you need to and does not distract while being pleasing to the eye. Same with the music, although the soundtrack feels a little bit distracting at places, it sets the tone amazingly.
-
Talking about the positives, the game has a couple problems too, most of them come from a problem of the game being rushed (look that up, long story). The cutscenes, for example, feel half-♥♥♥♥♥. It is not very bothering though since the devs probably realised everyone would just watch them once and it feels good to know they instead spent their time polishing the game. Then there are a few questionable design decisions. I'm not sure why there are hidden warp zones in the game. Nobody will look for them, because these levels are not made to be explored. A difficult, time consuming, fun game.

Super Meat Boy is a platformer, similar to Super Mario Bros., but a LOT more difficult.
There are no checkpoints: no chances: and the requirement of skill.

There are 8 worlds to this game.

The Dark Worlds.

I reccomend this game, for the default price, and most certainly if it is on sale.

Warning, this game WILL make you rage so hard, you will invent new insults to throw at your filthy blob of meat. You have been warned.

After playing it for 70 hours, I have to say, this is the most well-coded platformer I have ever played. The controls on keyboard and gamepad are just amazing... The first levels are easy enough for anyone to play through, but from chapter 2 and on it will get harder. From chapter 4 and/or Dark World versions of the chapter 2+ the game will get really hard and you will die countless times unless you are very good at this game.

It does have a few CONS I will list:

-Alt-tabbing will make your game crash very often if you're playing in fullscreen.
-Game crashes randomly, about 1 time per 10 hours.
-''Super Meat World'' has been disabled and you cannot upload more levels to it, because the devs didin't want to patch the game to prevent hackers from messing with the feature, there are a few thousands of levels on it I believe, but you will never be able to upload any more levels.
-There's very rare glitches where you can die in walls or go through walls.

Other than that though, this is a very amazing game, it's worth the price tag, it has over 50 hours of gameplay, 300 levels and it is addicting. The respawn timer is instant so you're always up to die again in the next few seconds if you are not careful. This game also has my favorite soundtrack ever made for a PC game. The graphics are not so bad, the sound effects are good... I can't praise this game much more, it's awesome, buy it now!

reviewText:
PURE. UNADULTERATED. PLATFORM BLISS.

Super Meat Boy is one hell of an adrenaline rush and by calling it that is an understatement!  You follow your tale throughout Team Meat's adventure as Meat Boy which is basically a cube of meat...that's not surprisingly a boy. His quest to take back his dearly beloved lady, Bandage Girl, from the evil cluthes of Dr. Fetus is an exciting tale of anguish, but determination. As Meat Boy trudges through the 300+ innovative and unrelenting stages based on the retro platformers of yesteryear, he meets some fellow characters from other popular Flash Games such as Commander Video (Bit Trip Runner) and The Kid (I Want To Be The Guy) that can be used with their special abilities to better or even undermine you in levels.

Be forwarned: THIS GAME IS HARD AS BALLS. You'll die, and die, and die, and probably even throw your pc out the window into the nearest freaking land heep of other computers that have been throwed out due to this game, but don't let this heed stop you from experiencing this. One thing to surely take from this game is how fair this aneurysm enducing experience is. The controls are precisely fined tuned and butter smooth which is heavily important in a twitch platforming game such as this. Even though this game boils down to being as hard as nails (especially apparent in later levels), each death is fair and most of the time caused by the player, him/herself, but with each and every nerve indusing calamity, it'll help you get a better grip and understanding of how to succeed in further attemps and better you in the future. For whenever you do conquer that one obstacle that's been blocking your way to success, the sense of accomplishment is unparalled and unrivaled. And before long, you'll be flying through with ease and flair like it's second nature!

Graphics are nailed right down to the very center. Nostalgia is definitely an apparent factors as the art style is showcased in gnarly 16 bit fashion. This is carried even further as the bonus secret warp zone stages are brought forth in pure 8 bit style. Worth mentioning are the multiple worlds that you progress though and the levels that follow. Each world has a specific theme that let's the player know where your hero is venturing off into. Each and every level follows through to that suit of representation which really makes you relate to Meat Boy for each and every scenario he ends up getting in.

I can't recommend this game enough! Video game references abound along with a plethora of snazzy, platforming stages to occupy one for days. This is the game that you should be letting your newborn play after he exits the womb. Or even after you Ram Jam your significant other, this is defintely the sweet spot of entertainment. So go out there bucko! No matter who you are, you'll definitely find something charming enough to warrant a purchase of Super Meat Boy.

The nice thing about this game is there are tons of curveballs that can take a strategy that supposedly works, and disprove it in an instant. The guy who made this game should be shot, torn apart, ran over by a truck and get eaten by a godzilla.

You know how theres always a hard level in a game that you just cant complete? The one that kills you hundreds of times and when you complete it you're whole happy that you finally got over that thing?
That game has about 300 levels of that kind.

Seriously though no one should get eaten by a godzilla.
*real review*
The first thing you're going to notice in this game is its beautiful art and awesome music (which reveals itself in it's full potential later on)

Difficulty aside it retains those cute little cutscenes (I really like them, personally) and can eat your time quite easly.
And when you complete a level you always have that smile on your face, the one the tells you you completed something hard (and then you're raging about the next level a minute later)

Conclusion:
Buy this game if you have a lot of patience and appreciate good artstyle (even if it's 2d) and soundtrack.
Buy it if you like challanges and if you're not turned off by hard looking levels (even if it really turns out to be hard)
Don't buy it if not anything of the above (oh and just FYI I tought I was patient before this game)

As for playing with keyboard, it's completely fine and playable controls wise on a keyboard (never tried with a controller). It really depends though with what you're more used to playing.
So don't worry about the controls

My final rating is somewhere around 8.5/10 just beacuse I have a feeling It should get this rating. Maybe even higher but for now I'll stay at that.

reviewText:
PURE. UNADULTERATED. PLATFORM BLISS.

Super Meat Boy is one hell of an adrenaline rush and by calling it that is an understatement!  You follow your tale throughout Team Meat's adventure as Meat Boy which is basically a cube of meat...that's not surprisingly a boy. His quest to take back his dearly beloved lady, Bandage Girl, from the evil cluthes of Dr. Fetus is an exciting tale of anguish, but determination. As Meat Boy trudges through the 300+ innovative and unrelenting stages based on the retro platformers of yesteryear, he meets some fellow characters from other popular Flash Games such as Commander Video (Bit Trip Runner) and The Kid (I Want To Be The Guy) that can be used with their special abilities to better or even undermine you in levels.

Be forwarned: THIS GAME IS HARD AS BALLS. You'll die, and die, and die, and probably even throw your pc out the window into the nearest freaking land heep of other computers that have been throwed out due to this game, but don't let this heed stop you from experiencing this. One thing to surely take from this game is how fair this aneurysm enducing experience is. The controls are precisely fined tuned and butter smooth which is heavily important in a twitch platforming game such as this. Even though this game boils down to being as hard as nails (especially apparent in later levels), each death is fair and most of the time caused by the player, him/herself, but with each and every nerve indusing calamity, it'll help you get a better grip and understanding of how to succeed in further attemps and better you in the future. For whenever you do conquer that one obstacle that's been blocking your way to success, the sense of accomplishment is unparalled and unrivaled. And before long, you'll be flying through with ease and flair like it's second nature!

Graphics are nailed right down to the very center. Nostalgia is definitely an apparent factors as the art style is showcased in gnarly 16 bit fashion. This is carried even further as the bonus secret warp zone stages are brought forth in pure 8 bit style. Worth mentioning are the multiple worlds that you progress though and the levels that follow. Each world has a specific theme that let's the player know where your hero is venturing off into. Each and every level follows through to that suit of representation which really makes you relate to Meat Boy for each and every scenario he ends up getting in.

I can't recommend this game enough! Video game references abound along with a plethora of snazzy, platforming stages to occupy one for days. This is the game that you should be letting your newborn play after he exits the womb. Or even after you Ram Jam your significant other, this is defintely the sweet spot of entertainment. So go out there bucko! No matter who you are, you'll definitely find something charming enough to warrant a purchase of Super Meat Boy.

reviewText:
Super Meat Boy is a tough as nails platformer where you play as an animated cube of meat who's trying to save his girlfriend (who happens to be made of bandages) from an evil fetus in a jar wearing a tux.

Our meaty hero will leap from walls, over seas of buzz saws, through crumbling caves and pools of old needles. Sacrificing his own well being to save his damsel in distress. Super Meat Boy brings the old school difficulty of classic NES titles like Mega Man 2, Ghost and Goblins and Super Mario Bros. 2 (The Japanese one) and stream lines them down to the essential no BS straight forward twitch reflex platforming.

Ramping up in difficulty from hard to soul crushing SMB will drag Meat boy though haunted hospitals, salt factories and even hell itself. And if 300+ single player levels weren't enough SMB also throws in epic boss fights, a level editor and tons of unlock able secrets, warp zones and hidden characters.

- Story mode, featuring over 300 levels spanning 5+ chapters

- Play as a Head Crab! (Steam Exclusive)

- 33 legitimate Achievements

- Warp zones that will warp you into other games

- Over 16 unlockable able and playable characters from popular indie titles such as, Minecraft, Bit.Trip, VVVVVV and Machinarium

-Epic Boss fights

- Full Level Editor and Level Portal (January 2011)

- A story so moving you will cry yourself to sleep for the rest of your life

Possibly one of the best platformers I have ever played. The stages are nice and challenging, it's fast paced, the music kicks butt, and the controls are great. One of the things that makes Super Meat Boy so amazing is that it never feels unfair. If you die, you just respawn at the beginning of the stage like nothing happened. The music doesn't even restart. Even if you die a hundred times, it doesn't effect your time whatsoever. The stages are short enough to where you can get back to the place you died in mere seconds.

But be warned, while this game ISN'T unfair, it will still kick your butt so hard, that you won't be able to sit. Team Meat brought back the extreme challenge of the NES days. If you are patient with this game, you will conquer it.

reviewText: Anyone who appreciates a time-attack platformer will want to check out Super Meat Boy. The game may have a reputation for being overwhelmingly difficult, but it does a good job of easing in different elements to prepare you for the hard worlds, so the difficulty is not unfair. The later levels do however become increasingly unforgiving and can require near perfect jumps and timing, meaning anyone easily frustrated may give up. The environments and music are very well polished, which lends character to a game like this with its simple mechanics. Retro warp zones, hidden bandages, boss battles, and unlockable characters all provide a break from the normal speedy gameplay. Unfortunately there are some occasional crashes, and the global leaderboards have been hacked to bits which is disappointing. Despite a few problems, Super Meat Boy's excellent gameplay outshines any of its flaws.

reviewText:
Recommended if :
- You seek great challenge from your games.
- You enjoy games that test you on your reflexes.
- You want a time sink with tons of content.
- You enjoy games with simple mechanics.

Not Recommended if :
- You don't enjoy being punished.
- Pop culture references bother you to a great extent (there are a few references to memes in the game).
- You don't own a controller.

Super Meat Boy is a pure 2D platformer created by the dynamic duo of Edmund McMillen and Tommy Refenes. It's greatly inspired by the charm and difficulty of games from the 8 bit era of gaming, however, it isn't at all weighed down by the issues prevelant in games of that time. The game is as simple as running and jumping, there are no power ups or alterations of the game's core mechanics. Super Meat Boy relies on it's level design and tight controls to flesh out the game, and where games of the past would have been tedius, SMB values the player's time. Deaths are quick, and respawns are almost instant. Playing through a world in this game may take you hours at first, but after practice, you can blast through levels in mere seconds. It's a game that you can pick up and play for any amount of time and have a good time, but also one that has hours of content behind it, thanks to hundreds of levels and a ton of unlockables. Super Meat Boy truly is a treat for any fan of 2D platformers looking for a challenge.

reviewText: It's impossible to point to just one element that makes Super Meat Boy such an extraordinary game. From the intense-though-always-fair difficulty and the inspired level design, to the pinpoint controls and catchy soundtrack, all of the different aspects converge into something that is truly outstanding. When you hear stories of the unrepentant dangers that stand in your path, it's easy to get intimidated by such a daunting prospect. But don't be. The beauty of Super Meat Boy is that it always plays within the rules, and the smooth difficulty curve gives you plenty of time to become acquainted with everything before the true tests are unleashed. Death is always just one misstep away in Super Meat Boy, but the rush of winning is so supremely rewarding that you won't be able to tear yourself away.8.7/10

reviewText:
A challenging, but fun platformer. Super Meat Boy delivers a good experience.

Graphics: The graphics are well-made, it looks like they intended it to be a flash game from the beginning if you ask me. I rate the graphics 9/10.

Gameplay: The gameplay is great, good old platforming. Beware though, the game is HARD. It's not just a little bit hard, the difficulty is near games released for the NES if you know what i mean. Don't be suprised if you fail a level multiple times, you'll pass it eventually. However, to compensate for the high difficulty, you have unlimited lives, so you don't have to worry about getting a game over. You can also find bandages on some levels which, if you collect enough, you will unlock a new character to play as. However, i do recommend to use a controller to play the game, as the keyboard controls can be a bit akward. Overall, the gameplay is great. 10/10.

Story: The story is very video game-clichê like, you have the main character, Meat Boy, who has a girlfriend, Bandage Girl. They love each other. The villain is Dr. Fetus, a guy nobody likes. One day, out of anger, he kidnaps Bandage Girl, and Meat Boy must rescue her. As you can see, the plot is VERY similiar to any Super Mario game. I give the story 6/10.

Music: The music is fantastic, it gets you warmed-up for some hard platforming action. Every theme fits perfectly where they are played. 10/10.

In conclusion, Super Meat Boy is a challenging, but rewarding and fun game. However, not everyone will appreciate the high difficulty the game has. If you don't like dying over and over, the game might not be for you. However, if you're a hardcore gamer who wants a good challenge, then pick this game up. You won't regret it.

Final Score: 8/10.

reviewText: This is the BEST GAME EVARRRRRRRRRRR

Super Meat Boy!

In this game, you must save your girlfriend, Bandage Girl, from the evil Doctor Fetus, who beats her up every time you meet him with her! The story is pretty much like every Super Mario game ever, safe the girl from the evil guy who's far too strong for you to take on without super powers.

Meat boy has one main 'super power' and that is running really fast! It helps in most situations, in some however, you most likely will not run but simply walk, because jumps are different when you run. The game's mechanics are quite simple, dodge incoming objects, try to survive long jumps, understand the way things are. The controls itself are quite easy to understand and you grow to become a pro. The game takes you on easily, becoming more difficult as you proceed through the levels until you're at the final stage!

The game seems rather short, but believe me, you'll grow to love it and play it over and over again, as most people I know do. The game is so simple, yet so difficult sometimes. You get to rage every now and then because your jump was too fast, or you didn't see an incoming object! But exactly that rage, keeps you playing, because you want to prove that you can dodge the spikes and get all the bandages.

Super Meat Boy is the perfection of the 2D platforming formula created nearly 30 years ago. Everything about the game suggests that the developers knew exactly what they were doing. From little design quirks to more noticeable ones. For instance, every level is specifically tailored to be able to be speed ran. Time Trials are implemented as a test of definitive skill. Different characters are thrown in as unlockables for you to experiment with their different gameplay/physics/controls. Hidden bandages and warp zones add an element of exploration to the game. Ect.\n\nThe controls are spot on and really compliment the obstacles. Without the precise controls and creative traps/obstacles, this game would fall apart. The difficulty is perfect, despite what some may say. In fact I find the difficulty much overhyped, the game isn't nearly as hard as a lot of NES games were. This is how a game is supposed to be. Games are supposed to challenge you, not every game is meant to be beaten by everyone who plays it, that's not a game". People who grew up with modern "games" that coddle you with a safety net and hold your hand with interlaced fingers while frolicking through a field of flowers need not apply."

reviewText:
Super Meat Boy is a special type of game. Its one that mainly appeals to the gamer who enjoys quick bursts of endorphins that are difficult to achieve. This platformer yeilds a learning curve that turns most people away, but if you have the guts and patients to jump, die, jump and die again, then this game is worth it!

Enter the world of super meat boy, where just about everything except the floor is out to turn you into the next preservative injected burger at your local restaurant! Due to the tight controls of Super Meat Boy, constantly dying can only be blamed on you...yourself...not the game...sad huh?
There isn't much of a story to speak of in Super Meat Boy, bandage girl gets stolen, and you pull a Mario to jump your way to the last world and jump on that evil Dr. Fetus'...fetus body suit thingy...

The gameplay is somewhat unique to the platformer genre, mainly because of the increased difficulty and the option to play through harder levels with multiple characters, that are suprisingly different and all fun to use! Throughout the game you will master verticle climbs, sprint jumps, black hole avoiding, dying, and speed, lots of speed. Oh yea and dying. You do alot of that, did I say that already?
Super Meat Boy possesses the NewGrounds Feel, or at least that is what I call it. It has much flash animation influence throughout the cut scenes, and the in game animations  and textures are simple, but work to your advantage. For example, many textures that are not immedialy touchable, mostly blend in to the other blocks, and the moving objects, such as spinning blades, are mostly what stand out.

All in all, Super Meat Boy is a highly addictive game, and if you have the time and patients to adapt to the steep learning curve, is a MUST BUY!

reviewText: Its awesome

Super Meat Boy.  The one and only platforming game I've played in the last two years, and it's very easy to explain why. It's good. In fact it's more than good because it's the most excellently executed 2D platformer since Super Mario World. In fact I'm going to say something about that. Everything in this game is a modern take on the retro style of 2D platform games, but as much as it takes from that time long ago, it doesn't completely thrive off of that. It is its own game too.

The gameplay is by far the first and foremost reason why I played this for two years.The controls are incredibly well done, because I never have to worry about something in the game screwing me over (except occasional lag spikes that can't be helped, I blame that it was meant to be on Flash). Every level is treated like a puzzle, and at points, obstacles in a level are treated as a puzzle. It is at times difficult to solve but never unsolvable. And through that you get into the thought process that it will be possible to beat this level as long as I keep trying new strategies. Which makes it addicting as hell, which I love.

The story is simple, but it allows you to fill in the blanks like most games back in the old days. I'm sure they had this in mind the whole time they were making it, and of course it shows through all of the references to older games it makes in easy and not so easy to reach places. The references range from obvious to obscure, but either way you'll at least find a thing or two you recognize.

The music will take you back just like the story does, but it's so well modernized that you wonder to yourself every now and again if you've heard this music before. You haven't, and it gives the game its own originality and atmosphere that you won't find in another game. Danny Baranowsky, the composer for Super Meat Boy is a legend, and this soundtrack will feel like you're going through one or that you are one yourself. That's one impactful soundtrack if you ask me.
